newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan urges Kabila to avoid Zaire bloodshed.
newsitem.headline: Japan urges Kabila to avoid Zaire bloodshed.

text.p: Japan has appealed to Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila to avoid bloodshed in his struggle with ailing President Mobutu Sese Seko over control of the African country, a senior Japanese Foreign Ministry official said on Thursday.
Ryuichi Shoji, director of the ministry's Africa division, said he met Kabila last week in Goma and urged him to avoid violence in Zaire's capital of Kinshasa.
It was the first formal contact by the Japanese government with the rebel leader.
Japan heavily depends on Zaire for cobalt supplies, importing about 1,500 tonnes last year.
World cobalt prices have risen since early this year, due to the civil war in Zaire.
Mobutu's hold on power has been almost broken by the advance of Kabila's rebels, who control about three-quarters of mineral-rich Zaire after seven months of fighting.
Mobutu, who has dominated mineral-rich Zaire for more than 30 years, is now in the Gabonese capital of Libreville for a mini-summit with other African leaders.
"We have to admit that Kabila is now a key player in Zaire, but his ability as a policy-maker is still unknown," Shoji told Reuters in an interview.
"Therefore, we told him (Kabila) that the international community is monitoring with great interest what's going to happen in Kinshasa, and his credibility is at stake."
